body.stage: [The accused entered court] --- Upon commencing at 9.33 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good morning to everyone. Madam Registrar, would you please call the case.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Good morning, Your Honours. This is the case IT-09-92-T, The Prosecutor versus Ratko Mladic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Registrar. I was informed that the parties have no preliminaries. I have one; but, meanwhile, the witness can be escorted into the courtroom. I'd like to give the guidance of the Chamber on timing of sending lists of documents to be used with witnesses. On August the 23rd, the Defence expressed concern about late notice of certain documents used by the Prosecution with Witness Doyle. The Defence then sought guidance from the Chamber about when such lists should be sent. The Chamber will not set any strict time-limits in this respect at this stage and is confident that the parties can find common ground on this issue without involving the Chamber. At the same time, the parties are encouraged to send lists of documents to be used during examination-in-chief as early as possible. The Chamber would expect that a first list of documents be sent no later than seven days prior to the witness's testimony. Such a list could then be complemented at a later stage following any proofing of the witness. And that is the guidance of the Chamber. Ms. Bibles, could you tell us how much time you would still need?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. I anticipate about 20 additional minutes with this witness.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Thank you for that information.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Begic. I'd like to remind you that you're still bound by the solemn declaration you've given at the beginning of your testimony. That is that you'll speak the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. You will now be further examined by Ms. Bibles. You may proceed, Ms. Bibles.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: WITNESS:
sp.p: RAJIF BEGIC [Resumed]

body.stage: [Witness answered through interpreter] Examination by Ms. Bibles: [Continued]

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Begic.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When we broke yesterday, you were describing being on Vrhpolje bridge and believing that -- and I believe the quote was: "We'd been abandoned to our fate." I'd like to ask you about the circumstances at the bridge at that point in time on the 31st of May, 1992.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, could P163 please be brought back to our screens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: First, could you tell us how far it is from the bridge to the water?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, the bring is about or or perhaps metres high.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And as we look at P163 on our screens, we see a number of buildings that are in the area around the bridge. What was happening with those buildings at that point in time, on 31st of May of 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. On that day, we passed by the buildings you can see on the screen. When we arrived at the bridge, we were facing them, so you could see all of the surroundings of the village of Hrustovo and part of Vrhpolje, and everything there was on fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a check-point near the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was one at the bridge itself. When you cross over the bridge and go a little further, at the cross-roads where you can take the direction for Ilidza, there was a sort of bunker where they carried out controls.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you tell us, looking at this photograph, whether that check-point would have on the left side or the right side of the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On the right-hand side of the bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: While you were at the bridge, as you described when we finished yesterday, was anything going on around that check-point?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. We just saw a lot of soldiers standing on the bridge there, and there were some soldiers standing by this check-point at the cross-roads where the road leads to Ilidza.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What were these soldiers doing as the beatings were going on?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, there was a group standing by the railings itself on the left-hand side, on the downstream side. They were standing there and they had their rifles in their hands, and some of the soldiers were walking around the middle of the bridge. They were beating those who were standing on the other side. They were cursing. They were walking around. They were beating people, and so on and so forth.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was anyone in your group resisting or fighting back?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not physically. But Hakija Begic, for example, said a few words quite loudly, and on the whole the others were mostly moaning and just looking at the ground, looking down in front of them. So there was no physical resistance, in fact.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yesterday you testified at, I believe it's 2151, lines through 11, that Miralem Ceric and his son Enes were taken into the slaughter-house and that you didn't see them again. Did he have any other sons in your group?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Miralem Ceric.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yes. Did he have any other sons who were still in your group at the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Miralem Ceric and his son Enes Ceric were behind us. His younger son, Midhet Ceric arrived at the bridge with us in the column. He was the first person there. If you are looking from the direction that we came from, he was standing there on the bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you see whether anything happened to him on the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. After they had spent some time beating the people and insulting them, one soldier asked loudly, Who was good at jumping into the water. And there was a soldier standing on the right-hand side by the railings there, Marinko Acimovic was his name, and he said I know that Cera knows how to jump into the water and then Nenad [as interpreted]

Palija, who was standing in front of him, ordered Midhet to jump into the water. Midhet did so. He climbed over the railings on the bridge and jumped into the water on the upstream side. As Midhet was swimming downstream, the water took him downstream, I saw four soldiers who were preparing their automatic weapons and leaning over the railings, and when Midhet appeared under them, they opened bursts of fire directed at him. Several moments later, you could see his body a little further down. The water had carried him downstream. You could see that his body wasn't moving, and you could see that the water was red with his blood, the water around him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And I just want to go back. Who ordered him to jump off the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nenad Kaurin, a soldier who was standing in the middle of the bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how old was Midhet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, at the time, I think he was about 30 years old.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. Who was next to be ordered off the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, as I have said, Midhet was the first person in the column, if you are looking from -- if you are facing from the direction that we came from. And then there was Munib Begic. When Midhet was taken downstream, you could hear someone say, Let's have the next one, and then there was a soldier who had searched and beat the people earlier on. He approached. He hit him a few times with a baton. He hit him on the head a few times with a baton an ordered him to jump. He just had a look to the left, climbed over the railings, and he jumped, and a few moments later, the same thing happened. The same four men leaned over the bridge. You could hear Munib swimming and these four men firing at him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how old - excuse me - was Munib?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At the time he was 27 years old.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was next to go over the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The next person standing by Munib was Enes Dezdarovic. He was under age at the time. He was between 15 and 16 years old. He was the next one. And to my right, two of his brothers and his father were standing to my right, in fact. He was also ordered to jump, and when this boy tried to jump into the water, and as hes with climbing over the railings, Jadranko Palija approached and shot him in the head at the time that he wanted to jump. He pushed him over the railings with his leg and when his body fell into the water and was passing under the bridge, the four men I have already mentioned fired at him again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At that point in time, was attention directed towards you somehow?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. After they -- these people had been killed, they started beating all the others who were still standing on the bridge. Some were thrown to the ground. Some were already lying on the ground. They kicked some of them. Hit others with their rifles. It was chaos. You could no longer distinguish what was being said and to whom. There was just a lot of terrible groaning. The elderly people who were standing on the right were groaning, so this maltreatment and these beatings lasted for several minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was happening to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was also beaten, as were the others. But somehow I remained where I was standing. In other words, I wasn't lying down on the bridge. Jadranko and Nenad came and punched me in the head while I was standing there, and there was Elmedin Begic whose turn came next.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And can you describe for us what happened when it became his turn?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. When it was his turn, a soldier approached and asked him who the lieutenant, the officer in Begici was, and he said, No one. He asked him who had weapons. He said he didn't know. Then they started beating the people again. They skipped him then and ordered me to open my mouth. Jadranko put the barrel of an automatic weapon in my mouth. And then someone said, Don't kill him on the bridge. Don't dirty the bridge. He should jump.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you, in fact, then jump?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I also climbed over the railings. I was in the middle, and then I dived into the water.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you describe what happened as you went into the water?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. As the water was up to my neck at the place that I dived into, I hit my head because there was a rock on the bottom. I turned around and I managed to climb out under the column, the mid-column, of the bridge. I was standing there and I heard the soldiers looking for me. They were waiting to see me swimming. I knew I had to pass by. I think someone said, The water will take him away. He's certainly been stopped by this column. And then I briefly took my leave, in a certain sense. I didn't want to swim. I didn't want to be an easy target for them. I decided to swim under water. Then I took off that white T-shirt that I still had on me and kicked it to the bottom of the river, and when I had gone downstream a metre or two, I swam under water, a little to their left, and when they noticed the T-shirt, they opened bursts of fire. While I was swimming under water, I could see this. And then, as luck would have it, I avoided all those bullets. I swam under water to the left because I wanted to reach the bank, and I managed to do that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How far down-river did you make it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I wouldn't know exactly. Between 50 and 60 metres.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you tell us, when you came up from your dive, where -- where in the stream of the river were you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. There are a lot of trees to the left of the river. A lot of bushes. There was one that was just a bit above the water. I managed to emerge by that bush, and as I emerged, I took care not to be seen. So only part of my head was above the surface of the water. I grabbed onto the bush, and that's where I remained, in hiding.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long did you stay in that location hidden by the bush?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, when I jumped off the bridge, I don't know what time it was exactly, about 5.00 or half past 5.00. I remained by the bush, observing what was going on on the bridge, and when everything was over, my intention was to get out of the river because the water was cold. However, I couldn't do so because there was still a lot of soldiers moving around by the river and in the surroundings, so I remained there. I waited for night to fall so that I would take advantage of the dark. So it was already a little dark when my intention was to get out of the water.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Let's go back to when you first came up in the bush. Could you see or hear what was going on on the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. You could see everything that was going on. But from that distance and through the branches, it was difficult to see everything. You could see people jumping off the bridge. You could see the bodies falling into the water, but it wasn't possible to identify the person who had jumped into the water. You could see the same four men who continued to fire. You could hear people groaning and moaning. They continued with their beatings. There was a lot of noise they were making. They continued cursing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were you able -- are you able to tell us how many bodies went off the bridge after you surfaced at the bush?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I saw two or three other bodies that jumped off the bridge, or were thrown off the bridge, after I had jumped. Not everyone jumped off the bridge. After the two or three bodies that jumped, the two or three people that jumped into the water, you could hear them opening bursts of fire for quite some time, and then there was silence for a while. You could no longer hear anything.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At some point, did you attempt to find other survivors from the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. When I managed to get out of the water, over the next few days, I spent some time walking around the area in an attempt to see if I could find anyone, but I didn't find anyone.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: My I just interrupt, Madam Bibles. At page 9, line 13, the witness says or is interpreted to have said: "After the two or three bodies that jumped, the two or three people that jumped into the water, you could hear them opening bursts of fire for quite some time and then there was silence for a while." Did you mean to say that the people who are jumping into the water fired shots? Or were they fired at?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

Yes. What I said was that from where I was in the water, I could observe the same scenario repeating itself a few times. The man would jump. Then the four would fire. After that, would you hear a long burst of fire. After the scenario repeated itself three times, then you would hear the long burst of fire. And then after that shooting, no more people jumped in the water and you couldn't hear any more moaning or cursing. It's as if there is nobody there on the bridge anymore.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What sort of injuries did you have in the -- after the -- the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was beaten on the bridge. I had some bruises around my eyes. When I jumped into the water, when I dived, I hurt my head. My skull cracked open in one place, yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You testified that over the next few days you spent some time walking around the area. What area did you stay near during those few days?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. After it got dark, then I was thinking that I should get out of the river, but I had already bled a lot and I was cold. So the water just carried me downstream. And then the next day, or a couple of days later, I woke up at the delta of the Sanica river, and I was there by a bridge, and I spent the next couple of days there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At some point, did you decide that you needed to go for help?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I spent three nights there where the Sana and the Sanica rivers meet, and then when I could no longer stand being there, I decided to leave and go somewhere. I decided to go to Andja Krlic and Vid Krlic. And so that one night when there was a storm, I took the opportunity and I went to their house, and I asked them for help.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And just to clarify, was this your godmother?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you actually -- were you able to reach her?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did, yes. Like I said, that night, when I decided to go somewhere else, it was a terrible storm. It was raining. There was thunder and lightening, so I used that very dark time to reach their house, unnoticed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you reached her, did she tend to your wounds?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I arrived after midnight. And in the state that I was in, I didn't dare to knock on the door. I hid in the barn. And only when it was light, when they came out of their house, then I said something. They received me. They told me that they knew what had happened. They brought me into the house, and then my godmother Andja brought some plum brandy to clean my wound on my head. She cleaned the area around my eyes, and then she put some kind of dressing on my chest. I put some dry clothing on, and I had a cup of tea.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You told us that her family -- this was a Serb family. Did they have Serb neighbours who were concerned for their own safety because you were with them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Her son Zeljko was also an armed soldier. At that time he just happened to be at home. The check-point that was not far from our houses was a joint check-point for the Serbian population in the surrounding houses. From Vehici [phoen]
to my godmother Andja's house, there was no check-point. At least I didn't see any. There was just one check-point more to the right, near the Stojnovics' place.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did someone turn you in to the authorities?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. After 15 or 20 minutes, I was so tired. At one point, I woke up. There was nobody in the room, and you could hear voices calling me to come outside. I went outside, and then I could see neighbours who had surrounded the house. They were armed and they were telling me to surrender.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did you, in fact, surrender?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I went out. I knew my neighbours. There was an officer with them. My godmother Andja and her son were standing there with them when I came out. Then the people who had surrounded the house also came, so we were all standing together in one place near the house.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. After you surrendered, did you receive medical care?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. At that point, no. This officer was in two minds, the one who came with the car and the neighbours. His only dilemma was what was I doing there. Who was I. Why did I come there. He was asking Andja. Actually, she explained to him that I was her godchild and that I could stay at their place, which is what he was asking. He asked, Can he stay with you for a couple of days until the situation calms down a little bit? She said, Yes, he can. But the neighbours who were with this officer were not in favour of my staying. They wanted him to drive me away from that place because I posed a danger for them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. Going forward in time, at some point in time, did you end up going to Manjaca camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. In July, when the inmates were taken to Manjaca that day, I was also in one of those trucks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where were you immediately before being taken to Manjaca?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After I was taken from my godmother Andja's house, they took me to the village of Tomina. That's where I received medical treatment. They interrogated me, and after this interrogation, I was released. Actually, I was taken to the village of Tomina which was across the river from our village, and that's where the refugees were located, from Begici. My mother was there and my youngest brother. We were some 20 days there. And then, after that, all the refugees from the neighbouring villages were transferred to the Krings camp in Sanski Most. And then after a couple of days, or three days, we were transferred to Manjaca.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long were you in Manjaca?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was there until the 16th of December, 1992.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And from there, you were eventually released?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. When the camp was disbanded, I was released with the other inmates. We went to the town of Karlovac.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did your mother and youngest brother survive the war?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. They were transported from the Krings camp before I was. They were taken to Central Bosnia. And then I think they went to Slovenia. Through the Red Cross, I think it was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you aware of whether or not an exhumation was done of bodies under the Vrhpolje?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Is interest any dispute about these matters.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: No, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Well, why then ask the witness?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Just --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Especially if you indicate that you need another 20 minutes. You've taken now approximately 30, and then to come up with matters which are not in dispute, and I take it that there is documentary evidence of it anyhow.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honour, I won't be asking more than one question with respect to this.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether the remains of any of your immediate family was identified in the exhumation?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And who was that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Many of them were found. Among them, my brother, Nedzad Begic, my younger brother.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, as I am coming to the end, I would ask that 65 ter 28366 be brought to our screens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: While that's being brought up, have you looked at a list of names, the list of names you see before you, before testifying?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And the list of names, can you tell us just briefly who these people are. How is it that -- that their names are all together?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. This is a list of the people who went to that bridge that day.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you seen or heard of any of the people whose names are on this list? Have you heard of any of them being alive since the 31st of May of 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Unfortunately, no.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honour, the Prosecution tendered 65 ter 28366 into evidence.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Your Honours, it's not clear who created this document, and we would object to this kind of documents.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: First question: Who created it?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, this was created from the witness's statement by the Office of the Prosecutor and then shown to the witness --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: It is --

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: -- over the weekend.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: It is extracted from previous statements and testimony, is that?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: That is correct, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: And also we would ask where in the indictment we have those names or this list?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, this would be for Scheduled Incident A71.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, this refers to, as I said, Scheduled Incident A71. There was a separate list filed with the names of the victims.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: We -- as we stated before, we would -- we would always object to the documents created in this way by the Office of the Prosecutor. It's up to Your Honours to decide what to do with this kind of document --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: What basis? I mean, of course, what we could do now, the witness recognises, as he has testified, that these are names of persons he knows were in the -- taken to the bridge. Now, of course, we could ask him to -- or to put on the record each individual name and ask him to confirm that this was a person. That seems not to be very practical. It's not clear to me on what basis you exactly oppose the admission of the list, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: It's more --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: What legal basis, I mean.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Legal basis: That it's more of a -- actually -- just a second.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: And it is different from the one -- from the indictment, so why don't they show the witness that list? We would object because it was created by the Office of the Prosecutor. It's -- it's, I think, not good to let parties to create documents and ask for their admission.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: A lot of photographs, for example, are produced by the Office of the Prosecution as well. I mean, I never heard that that makes them in any way inadmissible. Now, often we see that. But I'll consult with my colleagues about admission.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I have a few questions for the witness. Witness, I'll read the names, and you confirm by a yes or a no whether they were in the group that were led to the bridge. Elmedin Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Fuad Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Hakija Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Irfan Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Muhamed Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Muharem Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Munib Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Nail Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Nedzad Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Sacir Begic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Enes Ceric.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Enver Ceric.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Midhet Ceric.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Miralem Ceric.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Enes Dizdarevic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ismet Dizdarevic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Muhamed Dizdarevic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mirsad Dizdarevic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ismet Kurbegovic.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: No further questions?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Not with respect to this exhibit, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Now, is there any need to insist on the exhibit to be admitted -- have it admitted into evidence?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: No, Your Honour. The record is very clear at this point.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed and keep in mind that you went well beyond your 20 minutes.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: I apologise for that, Your Honour. We did reserve two hours for this witness and I was overambitious in my time. I have one last question.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please put it to the witness.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you describe for us the last time that you saw your brother Nedzad?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At one point when I was standing on the bridge. I was the fourth in line. My younger brother, Nedzad, was the last one in the column that was standing along the fence, and when I was jumping off the bridge, at that point I looked at him and he looked at me also. Then that was the only -- actually, that was the last time that we saw each other.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, I have no further questions.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Ms. Bibles. Mr. Lukic, are you ready to cross-examine the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour, I am.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Begic, you will now be cross-examined by Mr. Lukic. Mr. Lukic is counsel for Mr. Mladic. And you'll find him on your left. Cross-examination by Mr. Lukic:

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Good morning, Mr. Begic.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As you heard from His Honour, I'm going to be cross-examining you now on behalf of the Defence of General Mladic. Today, on page of the transcript, you talked about Vrhpolje and Hrustovo.

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Could the counsel please repeat the last part of his question. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you aware that Hrustovo and Vrhpolje were strong military points of the Muslim army?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know the brothers Vukanovic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you aware that they were the commanders of these military units in Hrustovo and Vrhpolje?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did hear about it, but I didn't know it myself.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And are you aware that, at the time, there were 900 members of the Bosnia-Herzegovina TO in Vrhpolje at the time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And are you aware that in Mahala and Hrustovo there were 400 members of the B and H TO?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you aware that on the 26th May 1992, there was a mortar attack initiated from Mahala on the Serbian parts of Sanski Most?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I was in Begici at the time which is 10 kilometres away, so I didn't see or hear anything like that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the time that you're speaking of, did you know that the fighting in Vrhpolje precisely on that day resulted in the death of ten members of the Serbian army in combat?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know that on that day 146 fighters of the TO of the Bosnia-Herzegovina forces surrendered in the fighting in Vrhpolje?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I'm hearing of that for the first time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And have you ever had heard of Amir Avdic, who was one of the commanders of those forces?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did you know that he was one of the commanders of those forces?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. At that point, no, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did you hear about that later?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Can we now please look at P163 on our screens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you were describing how people slipped through the gaps in the fence of the bridge or the railing, is this how this railing looked at the time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how high is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: metre. I don't know exactly. Approximately metre.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how is it possible for a person to slip through this railing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Through the top. Because the railing only has one bar going through the middle. And then they would slip through this upper part of it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'm sorry, I didn't understand you. They passed through what?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Through the railing. This is a picture of the bridge after it was repaired, after the war. It's an identical -- the railing is identical, but you could slip through this top frame of the railing. You could slip through it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you saying that the people were sliding through between the asphalt and that wrung, that railing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, you put to the witness that he used the words "slip through." Could you give us the exact line where he said so, so that we are able to follow your examination. Because a WordWheel search on the yesterday and today, only gives one -- let me see ... I only see the word -- oh, let me see. I didn't find it. Could you assist me.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: I'm trying, Your Honour. For example, today, on page 4.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Let me see. Page 4, you said.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: I have line 3. But let me look ...

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Page 4, line of today's transcript, I do not find anything of the kind.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: After that. I don't have the exact page and line. He was talking about Midhet. Here it was marked: He climbed over.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: He climbed over. That's not the same as slipping through, isn't it.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: But in his statement, I found that he said "through."

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: This statement is not in evidence, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: It will be. It will be.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Well, I do understand that you want to tender it soon.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yeah, I will tender it soon, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We'll wait and see. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Before you proceed, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: At page 21, line -- line 22, the witness says, after being asked a question: "I'm sorry, I didn't understand you. They passed through what?" The answer was: "Through the railing."

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: This is a picture of the bridge after it was repaired after the war. It's an identical -- the railing is identical, but you could slip through this top frame of the railing. You could slip through it. The point I want to raise with you is that he could slip through that top. Now, at page 22, you -- line 1, you say: "Are you saying that the people were sliding through between the asphalt and that wrung, that railing?"

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Now, if they were slipping through the top as he has already told you, it couldn't be between the asphalt and the railing.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: But then he confirmed what I asked him, because there was no possibility to -- there is only one gap in between the railing --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Let's not further --

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: [Overlapping speakers]

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Let's not further discuss it at this moment, but there certainly is some confusion --

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: You're confusing the witness. This is the point. Because he has given you an answer and you ask the same question again and ask it differently. He said they go over the top. Now you say it's between the asphalt and the wrungs. Obviously if it is between the asphalt and the wrungs, it means they are sliding on [indiscernible]
virtually, when in fact he says they are climbing on the top.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: There was nothing on the top to squeeze through.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: No, on the top he said this railing has a bar in the middle.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes. So --

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: So you jump over.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: -- only one bar. Only one bar. There is nothing to be squeezed through on the top.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, if it confuses us, it most likely would have confused the witness as well, whatever he answered. And if you say he confirmed that, it could be because he was confused. That, at least, is a possibility which we should exclude for your next questions. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: We'll go on, Mr. Begic. We'll get to that. I'll find it in your statement as well. You saw bodies floating downstream. You saw that from the bridge; right?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. From the bridge, you could hear someone below the bridge, but you couldn't see it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. But when people were hit, did you see --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we did see that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how far away would they float when you could see them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, after 30 or 40 metres, you could already see the water and a body floating on the water.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And then, when you grabbed onto a piece of wood when you first got out --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: -- all these bodies -- all the bodies of the persons before you, did they already go downstream?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know where they ended up, because we could see them floating down the river from the bridge, but not all the time because we were being beaten and everything else. So our attention was diverted and we could not watch these bodies for a very long time as they went downstream. I mean, you couldn't watch downstream any longer and you couldn't see where they ended up.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Can we now take a look of the statement of the witness from the 16th of April, 1996; 1D205.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recognise the statement that you gave on the 16th of April, 1996 at the court in Sanski Most?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the bottom of the page, is that your signature?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Could we please take a look at page 7 now in both languages, B/C/S and English.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Since this statement is rather condensed, there are no paragraphs so we'll have to count the lines. Today, you said that you got out of the water after 50 or 60 metres --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in line five in B/C/S and in line 24 on the same page in English, you say that you dived and swam under water for about 100 to 150 metres. Can you reconcile the two statements for us today? Can you tell us what is correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To this day, I cannot say exactly how far away it was from the bridge to that bush. Now, when I think of it, it seems to be about 150 metres. Sometimes I say 50. But, at any rate, the distance was at least 50 and then up to 150 metres. That would be the most accurate way of putting it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At any rate, you said in your statement that you no longer saw the bodies of the persons who got into the water before you, and you confirmed that for us today.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So they floated down these 50 or 150 metres. They floated downstream?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And where is the grave where they were found later on? That is unclear to me. Is it the grave below that bridge from which the people allegedly jumped or is it a different bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As far as I know, there are several graves. And the bodies of the persons who were on the bridge were identified. Some were found in the grave under the bridge and others at other locations.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Your Honour, I would need guidance from Your Honours. Are we going to have short sittings today and short breaks?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I think we have -- I -- I should have been more alert on the short sessions. If this would be a suitable moment for you to take a break?

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We'll take the break now and then resume at ten minutes past 11.00.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If we take short breaks then. I'm confusing you at this very moment as well. Apologies for that. Could the witness first be escorted out of the courtroom.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We will resume, after a short break, at 11.00. --- Recess taken at 10.39 a.m. --- On resuming at 11.01 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could the witness be escorted into the courtroom. Mr. Lukic, the Chamber was also a bit puzzled by the reference to "grave." I think the witness said something about an exhumation. Grave, exhumation, I do not know whether it was a primary or secondary grave, et cetera. But, certainly, the witness did not use the word "grave," but it may be in the statement. But, again, the statement is not in evidence and the Chamber has not read it.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Welcome back, Mr. Begic. Mr. Lukic will now continue his cross-examination.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]

Mr. Begic, just briefly I will go back to the bridge railing. We already have your statement on our screens, but we need page 5 in B/C/S and page in English. First of all, I would like to show the Judges that there was no ill-intent on my part when I referred to this.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

In the B/C/S version, we need line 12 from the bottom up. In the English version, we need line on page 6. Line from the top. Everyone can see it in the English version now. This is what is written: "He squeezed through the fence and jumped into the water head first." The same is written in the B/C/S version. I'm going to read B/C/S now. "He squeezed through the fence and then jumped into the water head first."

body.stage: [In English] This is just for the clarification that I really found it in the -- in the -- in his statement, and I wasn't misleading this witness, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Well, let's not discuss this any further. What you appropriately should have done is to put this to the witness because at -- certainly you confused the Chamber if you are referring to portions of a statement which the Chamber is unaware of and then ask questions about it. Please proceed, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: But also jumping through the fence. You can jump -- jumping through the fence is more in line with jumping over -- over the top rather than sliding underneath.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: I was clear, Your Honour. Exactly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]

We're not going to deal with this any longer, Mr. Begic. I'm going to move onto something completely different now, when you say that local Serbs from the village of Cosici and Stojinovici placed a check-point 800 metres from your village.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Could we please have page 2, lines 4 through in B/C/S, and page 2, lines through 9.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You speak about a commander here who brought the unit to your village on the 25th of May, and this is what you say. You see line 3: "That unit which come to our village on the 25th of May, 1992, was commanded by a commander with long black hair, tied in a ponytail. He wore round dark glasses." And then further on you say: "He wore black leather gloves which he never took off." Would you say the same thing today if you were to describe this commander?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Also, on the same page of the B/C/S version but line from the bottom up; and, in English, it is page 3, line from the top. You describe the 31st of May, 1992, so this is the day when these killings happened, as you had said. And again you describe this commander, and you say: "The unit was commanded by the Chetnik whom I previously described as having a long ponytail." Would you say the same thing today as well?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Now I'd like to ask you something. Since we are describing the check-point in Cosici and Stojinovici now, is it correct that Muslims had a check-point as well but in the village of Crnojevici at the time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know where that village is.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Crnojevic. Perhaps it was mistaken there.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
1D207, could we please see that in e-court.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Begic, I'll read through it so that it can be correctly interpreted. This is a transcript from the Brdjanin case. Page 6382. The date of the trial was the 31st of May, 2001, when you testified in that case, and Ms. Faveau-Ivanovic, or Mrs. Faveau-Ivanovic, asked you the following:

body.stage: [In English] "Is it not true that Muslims also set up check-points in their villages and hamlets?"

[Interpretation] And your answer at point 17 is: "It is true, they set up a check-point at the village of Crnojevici?" It hasn't been correctly noted here. What did you have in mind? Where did the Muslims set up a check-point at the time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can't remember this statement, a check-point in Crnojevici.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Could we go to the top of the page, please. Could you zoom in to the top left-hand corner so that the witness can see it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It says the witness is Rajif Begic and that he was testifying in open session. Do you remember testifying in the Brdjanin case?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You don't know what you were testifying about exactly at this point in time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was probably thinking about a station, a Vrhpolje station, but I didn't see any large check-points in the hamlets, so I couldn't really say that there was a check-point there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So you're telling us that on the 31st of May, 2002, in fact, you weren't telling us the truth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I'm not familiar with the existence of a village called Crnojevici. I don't know how it is that this name, Crnojevici, appears in the transcript.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Very well. We will move on.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, the language on the 31st of May is not unambiguous, and I think it would be fair to -- to the witness to acknowledge that. The question was: "You said yesterday that your Serb neighbours set up check-points. Is it not true that Muslim also set up check-points in their villages and hamlets?" When the witness said it is true that they set up a check-point at the village of Crnojevici, then it's unclear who are the "they," because in the question setting up check-points is referred to both by Serbs and by Muslims so --

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: No, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: -- the "they" is --

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: The question was Muslims, specific. Is it not true that Muslims also set up check-points. It is it true --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The question was introduced by: "You said yesterday that your Serb neighbours set up check-points."

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: "Is it also not true that Muslims also set up check-points?"

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If a witness then answers: "It is true that they set up check-points," there may be ambiguity as whether the witness responds to the introduction to the question or the question itself. That is ambiguous. I do not need any further discussion at this moment about it, but I would like to have it put on the record. You may proceed, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Your Honour, in this transcript he wasn't answering to my question. He was -- in this transcript he was answering to question of my colleague Fauveau.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, I said that from reading it that it seems, at least, ambiguous. Not to say that you're right or wrong, but at least there's some ambiguity in the day and that's what I wanted to put on the record, and you may now proceed. Please do so.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: If I can inquire that "they" is ambiguous in today's transcript or in the transcript from the 31st of May, 2002?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: 31st of May, Mr. Lukic. And, as I said before, you may proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]
In the same statement on the second page --

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

We no longer need the transcript. We need this witness's statement, 1D205. Page in both versions. It's the 14th line from the bottom in the B/C/S version; and it's the sixth line from the bottom in the English version.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Begic, here, you say: "The entire municipality was attacked. The town of Sanski Most itself and the villages of Hrustovo and Vrhpolje. It was relatively calm in our village up until the 31st of May, 1992." When the attack was carried out against the villages of Hrustovo and Vrhpolje, do you know how long it lasted?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether any resistance was mounted?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now very briefly, I'd like to deal with the part of your testimony when you say that Nedjo Sucur [phoen]
interrogated you in the school.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: He asked you whether you knew Nenad Kaurin; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Nenad, according to you, was one of the people who opened fire on the bridge; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You said that you knew him and that he was a member of the reserve police force; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: He also wore a blue police uniform and a blue cap.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, could we have a look at Exhibit P162.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Could we have that up on the screen, please.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Begic, this is an exhibit that we have already had a look at. It's a drawing of the Sanski Most municipality and the villages have been marked. We can see it now. Could we have one map shown on the entire screen. It would be easier?

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: English or B/C/S version, please?

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: B/C/S version so that the witness can see it more properly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]
With regard to this document I'd like to ask you the following. At the top, we can see various colours that reflect the ethnic composition of that municipality. Did you make this sketch?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Did I draw this map? No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you work out the ethnic composition of the population. It says in 1991 the ethnic composition was such and such, and in 1995 it was such and such.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Perhaps, but I can't remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you draw this map?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can't remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Very well. Here the ethnic composition of the population as represented in 1991 and in 1995. You have the English version of the map in front of you. Perhaps that is causing some confusion but it doesn't matter. I had a look at the map and calculated that there were 19 Serbian villages depicted on the map. Can you tell us what the ethnic composition of the Sanski Most municipality is today? What is the percentage of Serbs living in the municipality of Sanski Most today? Do you know anything about that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I don't.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So could we agree that there are very few Serbs in the municipality now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we could agree on that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Could we now go back to your statement, 1D205. Page 5, line 12.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, you didn't object to the admission of P162. Nevertheless, of course, it raises some questions. Ms. Bibles, you used this map, and -- which depicts apparently the ethnic composition of the various villages. The only thing you asked the witness about was whether it's in the southeastern area, that's where he lived, and you mentioned a few -- was it your intention to establish in any way the ethnic composition, either in 1992 or at 1995? Because if that's the case, you should have asked the witness questions about it. And if you did not intend to do that, why didn't you use a map without any ethnic compositions? That's -- again, Mr. Lukic, you did not object. But I think, in view of your questions, it's important for us to know what you intended to prove with this map because you didn't ask any question about what seems to be the core of this map. That is, ethnic composition.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, the intent of the question was as the witness was describing. Sanski Most in 1992 was to display Sanski Most as an area that had villages of all ethnicities, and particularly with respect to his area that they were mixed. That's correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Now, first of all, you didn't ask any such question from the witness, so it is not the appropriate way of establishing that by remaining silent on it and just putting the colours on our screens. That's one. Second, if it was your intention to intention to establish the composition, the ethnic composition of the villages in 1992, or at least at the beginning of the conflict, then I think there exists a one -- 1991 census, at least not unknown in this Tribunal, which gives the details. So then it would have been appropriate, first of all, to try to agree with Mr. Lukic about the ethnic composition of villages in Sanski Most and then to present that either as an agreed fact or to do that not through a witness which remains completely silent on the matter, but then, rather, bar table the census on Sanski Most. This is not the way the Chamber expects the Prosecution to proceed in these kind of matters. Irrespective of whether Mr. Lukic objects to the admission, yes or no. May this serve you as guidance. Mr. Lukic, sorry for the interruption. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]
We need to have a look at your statement, page 5 line 12 in the B/C/S version. It's page and line 23 in the English version. Here you mention --

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, we still don't know where we are on the English statement. We don't see the page, we don't see the lines. We can't count line 27 because -- that's better. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: And it's line 23, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: [Microphone not activated]
Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Here you say: "He told us to line up on the bridge in single file, half a metre apart, and take off all our clothes, except for T-shirts ..." Did you obey the person who ordered to you take everything off, apart from your T-shirts?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When they order you to take your clothes off, well, that person didn't say that everyone should remain in their T-shirts. Everyone was ordered to take their clothes off. Some took everything off apart from their T-shirts. Some remained in their shirts and trousers, but the person did not say that people should remain in their T-shirts.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Page 76, lines to 7, you yesterday said that someone remained -- some remained wearing their trousers, some wearing two T-shirts, or shirts, but no one kept their shoes on.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So what you said in your statement can't be accepted, what you said in the transcript should be accepted?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What did I say in the statement?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I asked you whether you obeyed this person. Did you obey him? How did you act?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we obeyed him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. My colleague asked you about the injuries you sustained today [as interpreted]
, and you said that you -- your eye had been wounded and your head as well, because of the beating.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You didn't have any other injuries?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I had been beaten in the stomach, the ribs, but I was visibly injured in the head when I was beaten. And when I jumped into the water I hit a rock, as a result of which I had a wound to the head.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Could we now have a look at page 7, line in the B/C/S version, and in the English version, let's have a look at page 7, line 21.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In your statement, line 7, as you can see, or, rather, it starts at line 6, towards the end of line 6. It says: "While I was swimming underwater, I felt that I had been injured in the area of the left shoulder." Were you wounded in that area on that occasion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When I was swimming underwater by the T-shirt, a bullet whizzed by, grazed my left shoulder, so I was only grazed. I didn't bleed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So you were wounded in the area of the left shoulder?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. No, I wasn't.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Is it correct that someone designated you as a person who had weapons?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. At the bridge, when it was Elmedin Begic's turn, when the soldier ordering us to jump from the bridge asked him who had weapons, Elmedin pointed to the right and said, They had. But he didn't say Raho had or someone else had. He said, They had weapons, and what he had in mind were the weapons that were handed over at the check-point in Stojinovic.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And then you go on to say that you were beaten by Chetniks on the bridge. What kind of insignia did they have, if you remember?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They had different insignia. Like I said, some were wearing military uniforms. Some were wearing blue uniforms. Some had Chetnik insignia. Some had just regular items of clothing, waistcoats, jackets, so it was all mixed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But among the soldiers who came on the 25th of May, 1992, you didn't recognise anyone because you were hiding. But your mother recognised your school friend, Dusko Savic; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Before and at that time he was living in Kljevci; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The second time when they came, they beat up three men: Kurbegovic, Ismet, Hakija Begici, and Sacir Begic; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The first time when they came on the 31st of May, they didn't beat anyone when we set off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So this was between the 25th and the 31st. When they came that time, is it correct that these three men were beaten?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They came a number of times and they beat these three men.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: According to you it was Ranko Cosic, Vico Ilic, Bosko Stojanovic who beat these men up; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did they also live in the neighbouring villages of Cosici and Stojinovici?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you saw these same people on the 31st of May 1992; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. They didn't come that day when they were taking us away.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Also in the Brdjanin case - we don't need to call up the document, it's page 6389 in e-court - you said that they wore different things on their heads, some of them had helmets and others were wearing different caps; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in response to a request by my colleague Ms. Fauveau, so in Brdjanin on the 30th of May, page 8689, when asked, you said that all men wore some kind of uniform - is that correct? - and you answered in the affirmative. You said yes. Would you still stand by that statement?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The interpreter did not get the transcript page and line numbers for the previous question.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Mm-hm.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If you would read the transcript, page 41, the interpreter didn't get the transcript page and line numbers for the previous question.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
The first page was 6389 and the second page was 6389, also. I just gave the line numbers, from 17 to 19.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And now I would like you to tell us this. In response to His Honour Judge Agius's question on page 6399, line 11, of the Brdjanin trial of the 30th of May, you said - and you gave a longer answer, I'm summarising: Members of these units were not members of the regular military force. Would you still say the same thing today?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, without knowing the context of, for example, "these men." Of course the Chamber, if it's not in evidence, has got no idea what "these men" are, what it refers to, et cetera. So if you want us to take these matters seriously you should, one way or another, either to provide that one page or -- so that we can place it in time that we can have the right reference as far as time and place is concerned. Are we still talking about the people coming to the village? Are we talking about the people taking him to the bridge? "These men" is really creating a puzzle for us rather than it gives answers. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Thank you, Your Honour. I'm going to try to correct this error right now. Can we please look at e-court 1D209, which is the page that I was referring to.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: We can only see a part of the question by His Honour Judge Agius.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

Probably we would need to look at the previous page, but we did not upload it. But we're going to show this exhibit -- actually, this exhibit, which we would like to tender. We have the answer of the witness. I will broaden my question so that it's clearer.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And so, Mr. Begic, I'm going to ask you in order to explain things better, thus, the people who came on the 25th of May, 1992, in uniform, Serbs, with weapons, and then these same people who came, the ones in uniform, with weapons, Serbs, on the 31st of May, 1990 [as interpreted]
, were not members of regular army forces; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Begic. I have no further questions for you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Lukic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Could -- Mr. Lukic --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: One second.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: I'm sorry, one thing. We were -- we had the statement ...

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: We had the statement of this gentleman, 1D205. We would like to tendered it into evidence.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Without any limits, Mr. Lukic, which means that all the inculpatory elements of that statement would be in evidence as well?

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: We can cut off the portions if Your Honours want us -- [Overlapping speakers]

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We do not want it. I'm just pointing at the consequences as far as the -- if you -- and, of course, there's another problem: If you want to tender this into evidence, then we are -- is this the statement taken by the local authorities?

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Not for the purposes of this Tribunal, which means that it does not fall within the scope of 92 ter.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: That's true, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Then I will skip -- I will withdraw our request. We don't need the statement since the gentleman answered all our questions.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, the Chamber gained the impression that you read into the transcripts all the relevant portions of that statement. Under those circumstances, and I think that is what you hinted at, that you were considering to withdraw tendering his statement.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If that is the case, then we don't have to decide on the matter. There was another issue about the transcript. Let me see. There was something about the year, 1990. Let me see ...

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: There was -- if you look with me at page 42, your question --

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Which page -- which line, Your Honour?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: 42. It is for me line 17: "... with weapons, Serbs, on the 31st of May 1990 ..." I may take it that you intended to refer to 1992.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: 1992. And I think that I said so and the witness heard the same.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Okay. Then that is corrected. There seems to be little chance of real confusion there.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Any -- if this concludes your cross-examination, I'll just check with my colleagues.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The Chamber at this moment has no further questions. Ms. Bibles, is there any need to re-examine the witness?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: No, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then, Mr. Begic, then this concludes your testimony in this case. I'd like to thank you very much for coming to The Hague -- yes, Mr. Begic. You wanted to address me. Please.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]

Yes. If you permit me, Your Honour, I would like to say something. I would actually like to go back to Mr. Lukic's question about the bridge. It's correct that I said that those were killed squeezed through between the railings, so I don't want this to be in doubt at any point, how my friends and my neighbours were killed. I said that we squeezed through and that is correct. Even today can you still squeeze through the railing, even though it's a little bit hard to see in the photograph. But the way in which Dizdarevic, Enes was killed is exactly the way I described it, and I would like the statement to remain just as it is.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, which I do understand now is that he squeezed through the upper part of the railing and what a bar below that.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: So just under the very top but not over --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
In the middle, yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: In the middle. This correction --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Begic, for that. Mr. Lukic, no further questions on that. Ms. Bibles, the same. Then thank you for this clarification. Then I, again, want to thank you - that was what I was doing - for coming to The Hague and for having answered all the questions that are put to you by the parties and by the Bench, and I wish you a safe journey back home again.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The witness is excused. He may follow the usher.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Groome, is the Prosecution ready to call its next witness?

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: In a few minutes, Your Honour. Based on my earlier conversation with Mr. Lukic, he thought that he would take the entire session, so we had arranged for the witness to be brought at noon. As soon as he said he was sitting down I sent an e-mail and they are bringing the witness over now, but it may still take a few minutes for the witness to arrive. I do have a short matter that I could deal with at this time to make productive use of the time, but it will be a few minutes before the witness is in the building.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. I see that. Now usually the last part of the morning session is a bit shorter. Now we could also, after you have dealt with the matter you wanted to raise, we could also take the break then and then have two sessions of approximately equal length.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: I think that would ensure that the witness is here at that stage, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. The matter you would like to raise at this moment is which one, Mr. Groome?

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: Your Honour, prior to the summer recess the Chamber had raised concerns about the fact that the Prosecution had not used consistent colours in the Sarajevo court binder to denote the locations of the VRS and ABiH front lines. We've examined the map book more closely and in fact we have used colours consistently, and we - in any map produced by the Prosecution - we've used the colour red to mark the location of ABiH forces and blue to mark the location of Bosnian Serb forces. The problem is in the VRS maps, some of which are reproduced, in those maps the colours are not used consistently. So thus in the VRS map reproduced at page of the map book, the

sp.who: #vrs used red to mark the location of the abih forces and blue to denote
sp.speaker: VRS used red to mark the location of the ABiH forces and blue to denote

sp.who: #vrs forces. they used the opposite colour scheme in the vrs map reproduced at page 49. so that's an explanation of the different colours, and if the chamber would wish us to create an explanation or insert to add to p3, which is that map book, the prosecution would be happy to undertake that
sp.speaker: VRS forces. They used the opposite colour scheme in the VRS map reproduced at page 49. So that's an explanation of the different colours, and if the Chamber would wish us to create an explanation or insert to add to P3, which is that map book, the Prosecution would be happy to undertake that.
JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I'd first like to take a look at what you just explained.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: They were the maps on pages and 49.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, I'm just looking at them now. I do see that opposite colours are used. I think, as a matter of fact, but I'm looking at my colleagues, that we should not in any way change any of the original maps, and I think that your explanation at this moment is clear to us and enables us to work on the basis of the material we find in that binder.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: And, Your Honour, should we ever use these maps with witnesses, we will remind the Chamber of the possible confusion.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you very much for that explanation. Mr. Lukic, unless there's any matter -- and I see that Mr. Mladic apparently wants to consult with you. Perhaps you --

sp.speaker: THE ACCUSED:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
I would just like to say a couple of things.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Mladic, you first have to consult with Mr. Lukic about what you intend to say because you're represented by him.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And perhaps what we best could do is to take the break now, both for the witness to arrive and for you, Mr. Lukic, to further consult with Mr. Mladic. We take a break and we resume at ten minutes past 12.00. --- Recess taken at 11.50 a.m. --- On resuming at 12.14 p.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, we ended the last session you consulting with Mr. Mladic. I do understand from your body language that there's nothing to be raised at this moment.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: That's true, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then we'll proceed. Is the Prosecution ready to call its next witness.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, Ms. Hochhauser.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: The witness is present but before I call him into the courtroom if I may just address two matters briefly.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please do so.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: One is the issue of -- sorry. The first is that the Prosecution provided to the Defence a proofing note of September, dated September 2012. We provided at this point that note both in English and B/C/S. That proofing note contains approximately 12 corrections made to the witness's ICTY amalgamated statement which we intended to offer today under -- pursuant to 92 ter. It also contained additional details of the information regarding the witness's interaction with Mr. Mladic in April of 1994. During the recess just now, I approached Mr. Ivetic and asked if he would have an objection to my showing the corrections contained in that proofing note to the witness on paper during the examination rather than leading each of the corrections separately. Mr. Ivetic indicated to me that it would be his preference to have the whole proofing note shown to the witness, including the additional information regarding Mr. Mladic. I've now done that during the break. It's been shown to the witness outside the courtroom, and so, Your Honours, if -- if it pleases the Court, and that route is acceptable to the Court, I would ask that that proofing note be allowed to be assigned a 65 ter number and we'll show to the witness during the course of the examination.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. I'm a bit confused. 65 ter numbers are not assigned but are -- by yourself, isn't it?

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Ah, yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: So therefore there's no need --

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: I'm sorry, I just meant to add it to our 65 ter list.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: 65 ter list, yes.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: And the number would be 28371.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Mr. Ivetic, no objections against adding it to the 65 ter [overlapping speakers]

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Nothing, Your Honours. It's of an accurately reflect -- the statement -- the discussions have been accurately reflected that took place during the pause.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Leave is granted to add the proofing note to the 65 ter exhibit list.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: I would just add to that, because this came up unexpectedly, although we had -- we had entered into e-court just the redacted version that we thought we would be showing, the entire proofing is not yet in e-court but I have hard copies to provide to the witness and to the Bench, and we hope that it will be up in e-court within the next five to ten minutes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: That's appreciated. And if would you provide the Bench with the hard copies already, that would assist us. Any other matter? If not ...

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The next witness the Prosecution calls will be, Ms. Hochhauser?

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: It's Mr. Hurko Sefik. I'm sorry, Mr. Sefik Hurko. I apologise. And while he is being brought in, Your Honours, I would just point to the fact -- to the adjudicated facts which bear upon his testimony. They are adjudicated facts 1127 through 37, and 1225 -- I'm sorry, I apologise. 1215 through 1217. Where the evidence in his statement has been completely covered by the adjudicated fact, the amalgamated statement has been redacted as per the -- as per the practice of the Court.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. No protective measures?

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Hurko --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: -- I presume. Mr. Hurko, before you give evidence, the Rules require you to make a solemn declaration. The text is now handed out to you. May I invite you to make that solemn declaration.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
I solemnly declare that I will speak the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: WITNESS:
sp.p: SEFIK HURKO

body.stage: [Witness answered through interpreter] Examination by Ms. Hochhauser:

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Hurko. Please be seated. Mr. Hurko, you'll first be examined by Ms. Hochhauser. You'll find her to your right. Ms. Hochhauser, you may proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Hurko, good morning, or good afternoon.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you please tell the Chamber, are you currently employed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'm retired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And where is it that you live now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In Sarajevo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Hurko, you have given -- you gave a statement --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Hochhauser.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: It's not uncommon to start with the first question whether the witness would state his full name and date of birth, for the record.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: I apologise.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, could you please state your full name and date of birth.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My name is Sefik Hurko. I was born on the 22nd of November, 1957, in Rogatica.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Hurko, in -- on 24 January 1999, you gave a statement to the ICTY; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And prior to that, on 16 November of 1994, you gave a statement to local authorities in Bosnia; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, on the 1st of September, 2011, did you have the opportunity to review an amalgamation of those two previous statements into one document?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: If I could ask the usher to please put 65 ter number 28362 on the monitor.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, do you recognise -- I see we're looking at the first page. Do you recognise the signature on that page?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: And if we could turn to the last page of the document. I apologise. The page before. So it would be page 13.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes. I do recognise it. It's my signature.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. Did you have an opportunity to review over this past weekend and yesterday a copy of this statement in B/C/S?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And is it correct that yesterday you noticed two additional changes that you wanted to make. One being that in paragraph 41, the third sentence should read 10 July -- "10 June" where it now reads "10 July"?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in paragraph 42, where it reads -- where the first sentence begins, "A couple of days after that," that the "that" should be changed to "on July."

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, on the 2nd of September, did you make a number of other observations and changes that you would like to make or small corrections that you would like to make to the statement?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: If I could ask, please, for 65 ter number 28371 to be shown to the witness.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. And this is, just for reference, this is the information report that I was just referencing. I believe it's up in e-court now.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Let's have a look at it. And it looks very much the same as what we received in hard copy a minute ago. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. HOCHHAUSER:
sp.p: Great. And I see also that the B/C/S version of it is there as well.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, have you had an opportunity to review this document?
